title: import numpy in shell view puased at startup . (version 3.3.0b3)
body:
I  cloned thonny version 3.3.0b3 and found  a strange thing in shell view.

When I tried to import numpy in shell view, it will paused . 
I needed to press  an extra Enter key to get  it run .

My simple numpy program do  "Run in current Script"  will pause at startup and needs an an extra Enter.
But  the same program do "Run current script in terminal"  just normally.

By the way .   My laptop os is Win10 64bit.

```

    self._runner.start()
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 102, in start
    self.restart_backend(False, True)

  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 1254, in _init_
    super().__init__(clean, get_interpreter_for_subprocess(executable))
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 1062, in _init_
    super().__init__(clean, executable)
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 771, in _init_
    self._start_background_process(clean=clean)
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 781, in _start_background_process
    env = get_environment_for_python_subprocess(self._executable)
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 1393, in get_environment_for_python_subprocess
    overrides = get_environment_overrides_for_python_subprocess(target_executable)
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\running.py", line 1440, in get_environment_overrides_for_python_subprocess
    target_executable, this_executable
  File "C:\Users\cscm1\AppData\Local\Programs\Thonny\lib\genericpath.py", line 100, in samefile
    s1 = os.stat(f1)
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 3] El sistema no puede encontrar la ruta especificada: ''
```

It turned out he had following in configuration.ini:

```

[run]
...
backend_name = CustomCPython
...
[CustomInterpreter]
used_paths = ['']
```

ie. custom executable was not specified

title: Expression box for while/for test may be mislocated
body:
(Thonny 3.2.7 Win10 64 Python 3.7.6 Tk 8.6.9)
When I do nicer debugging (Ctrl+F5) and stepping (F7) through my simple gcd code
```
def gcd( a, b ):
    while a != b:
        if a>b:
            a = a-b
        else:
            b = b-a
    return a
g = gcd(44,12)
```
The evaluation overlay of `a != b` is shown in a wrong line:
![Thonny_gcd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5374048/78073888-fb398080-73a1-11ea-853f-adcf4c3e0119.png)

As I want to use Thonny in my 101 prog class, thats a little bit frustrating.

title: Assistant asks for MyPy annotations in user code
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/640) by me.**

----------------------------------------

```
import json
from collections import Counter

f = open("e4ebb352-5953-4f97-a16e-39f5a578e35c-UnLocode.json")
d = json.load(f)
print("count", len(d))

per_date = {}
dates = Counter()
codes = Counter()

for e in d:
    date = e["changeActivationDate"]
    dates[date] += 1
    codes[e["code"]] += 1
    
    if date not in per_date:
        per_date[date] = []

f.close()
print("Dates", dates)
print("Codes", len(codes))
```

title: Problem with Thonny and click package.
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/637) by bjwest (Bitbucket: [bjwest](https://bitbucket.org/bjwest)
 GitHub: [bjwest](https://github.com/bjwest)
).**

----------------------------------------

I'm checking out [click](https://palletsprojects.com/p/click/) with Thonny but get the following error window entitled "Problem when handling 'ProgramOutput'" when I try to run the sample program from the documentation page:


```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/johnny/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/workbench.py", line 1432, in event_generate
    handler(event)
  File "/home/johnny/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/shell.py", line 222, in _handle_program_output
    msg.data[0], ("io", msg.stream_name, "vertically_spaced")
  File "/home/johnny/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/shell.py", line 406, in _insert_text_directly
    if "\a" in txt:
TypeError: argument of type 'int' is not iterable
```


The error only occurs if I run it from Thonny, if I run from from the command line, it works as it should.  If I comment out line 7, I get the same traceback in both Thonny and the command line.  If I comment out the hello method and replace it with my own that takes no parameters, I get no error with line 7 commented out, but the above error window returns when I uncomment it.

This is the sample program:

```
import click

@click.command()
@click.option('--count', default=1, help='Number of greetings.')
@click.option('--name', prompt='Your name',
              help='The person to greet.')
def hello(count, name):
    """Simple program that greets NAME for a total of COUNT times."""
    for x in range(count):
        click.echo('Hello %s!' % name)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    hello()
```

title: Wrong line highlighted in loop in function call
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/628) by Alex Hall (Bitbucket: [Alex_Hall](https://bitbucket.org/Alex_Hall)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

When running this code:


```
# bla bla
# bla bla

def main():
    for i in range(3):
        pass
    
    print(1)

main()
```

This is what happens when it should highlight `pass`:

![Screen Shot 2018-12-16 at 16.46.23.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/gXnbod/images/1330506934-Screen%20Shot%202018-12-16%20at%2016.46.23.png)

The above code is a minimal example. The problem only happens:

1. Inside the function
2. Which has a few lines before it (blank lines will also do)
3. In a loop
4. With some code in the function after the loop

The exact line number of the function definition changes the result. If you add more lines before the function, you have to add more lines to the body to observe the bug.

Here is another case of what looks like the same problem under quite different conditions:


```
# bla

class A:
    x = 1+2
```

Here it highlights the wrong line for `1+2` after stepping into the class definition. And if you replace `# bla` with a function definition, it shows that function definition instead of the class.

body:

 ).**

----------------------------------------

When debugging this code:

```
try:
    raise TypeError()
except:
    print(1+2)

print(3+4)
```

after evaluating `TypeError()`, it jumps to the end of the program. I can't step through the parts that happen after. `raise ValueError()` has the same result, while `1/0` or `assert 0` work fine, so something seems wrong with the `raise` statement.

title: Autostart Thonny on boot
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/626) by Gerard Gilliland (Bitbucket: [gerardgilliland](https://bitbucket.org/gerardgilliland)
 GitHub: [gerardgilliland](https://github.com/gerardgilliland)
).**

----------------------------------------

I chose bug -- but it is probably me. 
I am attempting to start a python program in Thonny on startup.

------------- instructions to configure systemctl -------------

[https://raspberrypi.stackexchange.com/questions/85782/running-a-script-at-bootup-good-practices-rc-local-falling-other-options](Link URL)

Create a new systemd unit with:

rpi ~$ sudo systemctl --force --full edit thonny.service

In the editor insert these statements, save it and quit the editor:


```
[Unit]
Description=Service to start thonny
Wants=graphical.target
After=graphical.target

[Service]
User=pi     # or must it run as root? Then omit this line
#ExecStart=/home/pi/thonny   # or where your program is
ExecStart=/home/pi/testAutostart.py   # replaced the above line with this

[Install]
WantedBy=graphical.target


```
Enable the new service:

rpi ~$ sudo systemctl enable thonny.service

reboot.

Check with:

rpi ~$ systemctl status thonny.service

rpi ~$ systemctl cat thonny.service

Edit again with:

rpi ~$ sudo systemctl --full edit thonny.service


--------------- testAutostart.py -------------

```
#!/usr/bin/thonny
# added the above line
# testAutostart.py

import time

cmdfile = "cmdfile.txt"
cf = open (cmdfile,"w")
cmd = 1
cf.write (str(cmd))
cf.close
isRunning = cmd
cntr = 0
wait = 10

while isRunning == cmd:
    cntr += 1
    print("Hello World:", cntr)
    cf = open (cmdfile,"r")
    cmd = int(cf.read())
    cf.close
    if isRunning != cmd:
        print ("check interrupt")
        if cmd == 0:
            import os
            os.system("sudo reboot -h now")
        else: # incremented
            exit()

    if cntr > 100:
        cntr = 0
        # clear the shell
        
    time.sleep(wait)

```



---------------- cmdfile.txt ----------------

```
1

```


-------------- error 203--------------------

```
pi@raspberrypi:~ $ systemctl status thonny.service
● thonny.service - Service to start thonny
   Loaded: loaded (/etc/systemd/system/thonny.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
   Active: failed (Result: exit-code) since Fri 2018-12-14 10:27:26 MST; 8min ago
  Process: 549 ExecStart=/home/pi/testAutostart.py (code=exited, status=203/EXEC)
 Main PID: 549 (code=exited, status=203/EXEC)

Dec 14 10:27:26 raspberrypi systemd[1]: Started Service to start thonny.
Dec 14 10:27:26 raspberrypi systemd[1]: thonny.service: Main process exited, code=exited, status=203/EXEC
Dec 14 10:27:26 raspberrypi systemd[1]: thonny.service: Unit entered failed state.
Dec 14 10:27:26 raspberrypi systemd[1]: thonny.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'.
pi@raspberrypi:~ $ 


```

------------ analysis --------------------

```
status=203 is file not found
is the file not found 
testAutostart.py 
or
/usr/bin/thonny
or 
/usr/bin/python
or 
/usr/bin/python3
or 
/usr/bin/python3.5
or
is status=203 something else

```


------------ modifications --------------------

```
in systemctl replaced:
ExecStart=/home/pi/thonny   # or where your program is
with
ExecStart=/home/pi/testAutostart.py   # or where your program is
tried
ExecStart=/home/pi/thonny testAutostart.py   # or where your program is


```

in testAutostart.py top line added:

```
#!/usr/bin/python

```
then it changed to 

```
#!/usr/bin/thonny

```

title: Custom __repr__ and debugger causes error
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/604) by Austin Bart (Bitbucket: [acbart](https://bitbucket.org/acbart)
 GitHub: [acbart](https://github.com/acbart)
).**

----------------------------------------

I don't know whether there's a great solution to this, but I thought I'd bring it up. I encountered this issue while trying to demonstrate some code in class.

Basically, I created a custom class:


```
class Dog:
  def __init__(self, name):
    self.name = name
  def __repr__(self):
    return "Dog "+self.name

ada = Dog("Ada")
```


While stepping through this code in the debugger, I encounter an Attribute Error when the backend attempts to export the value using the repr function. During the creation of the instance, when it is available in memory but does not have all of its attributes, the system attempts to create a string representation of the object. However, this causes an attribute error since it isn't done initializing it yet. In theory, I could add conditional checks or try/catches, but that doesn't really strike me as the right model to show students.

Full traceback:

title: problems occur when a file exists in the directory with the name of unused module

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/603) by Taz (Bitbucket: [tazr42](https://bitbucket.org/tazr42)
 GitHub: [tazr42](https://github.com/tazr42)
).**

----------------------------------------

If the folder a program is running in has any files with the same name as a module (even if not used in the program being written), it can crash the program and it won't run it.

For example, create a program called pickle.py that has either an input or a syntax error in the code. Create a new file called whatever you want in the same directory. It will not work.

Essentially it will import from the current directory even if the program you're running doesn't import that file. It will work in IDLE however.

I appreciate if I'm writing a program that imports turtle and I have a file called turtle that it will crash, but when you have a file called pickle and you're not doing any file handling in your program, it shouldn't cause an issue.

There's so many modules that can cause an issue it gets problematic with a) students who have lots of test programs, and b) teachers who have programs to test their own sorts etc that aren't proper replacements for the modules.

title: Shell behavior with quoted parentheses
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/590) by Josh Rippon (Bitbucket: [cs-jrippon](https://bitbucket.org/cs-jrippon)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

The shell ignores closing parentheses when contained inside a quotation.  This can confuse students when they make certain errors:


```
print('Hello World!)

print(Hello')

'a'+('b'+'c)
```


While these are invalid statements and it doesn't make sense to try to run them, it would be helpful if the shell behaved like the python interpreter so students could at least see there is an error.

Related, it would be helpful to have some keystroke (maybe a semicolon?) or button to force execute the shell statement.  It is not always clear how to recover and get back to the prompt once the shell enters multiline mode and is waiting for a closing parenthesis.

Thank you for your consideration!

body:

 GitHub: [schellenberg](https://github.com/schellenberg)
).**

----------------------------------------

I'm using the [bitio ](https://github.com/whaleygeek/bitio) python module, which has worked really well with Thonny for the past year. However, a student who was using the newest version of Thonny (3.0.5) attempted to use the same code the rest of the class was successfully using with Thonny 2.1.22, and received an error originating from backend.py. I did some testing, and when attempting to run one of the example programs from the bitio module (std_image.py), the traceback is as follows:


```

    for handler in self._import_handlers.get(module.__name__, []):

Browsing the issues, I noticed that this is suspiciously similar to the [PROBLEM WITH THONNY'S BACK-END: ...obj no attribute '_w' issue number 584](https://bitbucket.org/plas/thonny/issues/584/problem-with-thonnys-back-end-obj-no)

title: "Laggy" text
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/576) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

I have just upgraded to 3.0 and find that typing or selecting text is extremely "laggy" and makes the editor very unpleasant to use. I didn't have this issue at all on previous versions

title: Error in outline, when you click at function name opens an error windows
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/574) by George Moraes (Bitbucket: [gg4016](https://bitbucket.org/gg4016)
 GitHub: [gg4016](https://github.com/gg4016)
).**

----------------------------------------

I am using 3.04, but this behaviour is the same with all 3.* versions, that problem didnt happen in 2.*

That is the error message

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\DATA\Thonny\lib\tkinter\__init__.py", line 1705, in __call__
    return self.func(*args)
  File "C:\DATA\Thonny\lib\site-packages\thonny\plugins\outline.py", line 146, in _on_double_click
    code_view.select_lines(lineno, lineno)
AttributeError: 'CodeView' object has no attribute 'select_lines'

I am going to attach the image
Thanks 
George

title: "Highlight matching names" and "Highlight local variables" makes editor very slow
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/573) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

in version 3.0.4 it takes about half a second to display a single character in editor workspace
when typing same code in shell workspace it works with no problems 

i'm using windows 10 64-bit

title: ssl.SSLError in "Manage Packages..."
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/572) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

After selecting menu option "Tools -> Manage Packages..." in Thonny editor, whatever I try in the "Manage packages" window (find some package or just click on an installed package), I got an internall error:

```

title: New Thonny version reopening windows, loading some __main__.py file in subprocess
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/571) by Austin Bart (Bitbucket: [acbart](https://bitbucket.org/acbart)
 GitHub: [acbart](https://github.com/acbart)
).**

----------------------------------------

I just installed the new stable version of Thonny on Windows, and it's acting strange. When I open Thonny, the window repeatedly "closes" and then reopens. It doesn't seem to be the application restarting, just the GUI sort of redrawing itself (slowly, with lots of grey and black parts). I can't really do anything without it triggering this redraw repeatedly.

Possibly related, but when I loaded it up, it also popped up a __main__.py file from the subprocess module for Jedi (if I'm parsing the path correctly). I don't recall ever opening this file before, so I'm pretty sure it's Thonny doing the opening. 

I've attached a video of this behavior.

I'm a little nervous right now, since I have my students install Thonny a week from Wednesday - think this stuff will be cleared up quickly, or should I have them install a previous version?

title: Error in Debug mode (DebuggerResponse)
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/570) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Hello,

With 3.0.1 and 3.0.3 same problem happens.

Even when using simple "Hello World" programm, "Run" is fine, 
but "Debug nicer" and "Debug faster" show:
'DebuggerResponse' object has no attribute 'sequence'

When upgraded to 3.0.3 error did not show up immediately, but came after palying
around with debug/breakpoinst/ etc..

title: Can't open Thonny on Mac by double clicking on py file
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/566) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

If Thonny is already open, and I open a python file by double clicking in finder, Thonny goes invisible/ is hidden. I see the opening animation and it being open on the dock but the entire GUI is gone. The menu bar is visible still. Only option is to open within Thonny but that is somewhat annoying and I forget to do it and have to quit and reopen Thonny.
I'm on MacOS Mojave.

title: Tabs
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/565) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

If you accidentally make an infinite loop that's printing tabs, you get asked over and over again if you want to print tabs or 4 spaces. You can keep choosing both, either way it doesn't stop asking and you can never get to stop your program. You have to kill Thonny to stop it.

It should read:

```

title: rgb()
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/526) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Greetings,

RGB color does not seem to work.  We created a function to get around the problem.  See below, but the issue would be nontrivial for the beginner.

```
def rgb(r,g,b): #Red Green Blue -> HTML Hex Code
    r2=hex(r)[2:]
    if len(r2)<2:  r2=r2+"0"
    g2=hex(g)[2:]
    if len(g2)<2:  g2=g2+"0"
    b2=hex(b)[2:]
    if len(b2)<2:  b2=b2+"0"
    rgb2=r2+g2+b2
    return "#"+rgb2
```

title: Thonny + sqlanydb (InterfaceError: Could not load dbcapi) on Mac
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/516) by Maku Donaldu (Bitbucket: [utudeng](https://bitbucket.org/utudeng)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

After installing Thonny and sqlanydb I connected to SQL Anywhere 17 with a standard test (copied from test.py).

Received an InterfaceError message:
   >>> %Run 'Proovime test db.py'
   Traceback (most recent call last):
     File "/Users/OM/Projects/Proovime test db.py", line 5, in <module>
       import sqlanydb
     File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 971, in _find_and_load
     File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 955, in _find_and_load_unlocked
     File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 656, in _load_unlocked
     File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 626, in _load_backward_compatible
     File "/Users/OM/.thonny/BundledPython36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sqlanydb-1.0.6-py3.6.egg/sqlanydb.py", line 469, in <module>
       class Connection(object):
     File "/Users/OM/.thonny/BundledPython36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sqlanydb-1.0.6-py3.6.egg/sqlanydb.py", line 471, in Connection
    def __init__(self, args, kwargs, parent = Root("PYTHON")):
    File "/Users/OM/.thonny/BundledPython36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sqlanydb-1.0.6-py3.6.egg/sqlanydb.py", line 422, in __init__
    'libdbcapi_r.dylib')
    File "/Users/OM/.thonny/BundledPython36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sqlanydb-1.0.6-py3.6.egg/sqlanydb.py", line 416, in load_library
       raise InterfaceError("Could not load dbcapi.  Tried: " + ','.join(names))
sqlanydb.InterfaceError: Could not load dbcapi.  Tried: dbcapi.dll,libdbcapi_r.so,libdbcapi_r.dylib
>>> 

I followed instructions "Installing sqlanydb on Unix and Mac OS X" (as I have Mac OS X 10.13.6):
http://dcx.sap.com/sqla170/en/html/3be1807a6c5f1014b9618468518bc633.html
There was a note "*If you are using Mac OS X 10.11, then you must set the SQLANY_API_DLL environment variable to the full path to libdbcapi_r.dylib*." and therefore added to bash_profile:
“export SQLANY_API_DLL=“/Applications/SQLAnywhere17/System/lib64/libdbcapi_r.dylib". But that did not change anything. What could be the problem? Thank you in advance.

title: Opening files from Finder or from Thonny's  View > Files do not show up in configuration.ini
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/480) by Carlos (Bitbucket: [caseminario](https://bitbucket.org/caseminario)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

Hi, I'm running Thonny 2.1.21 (Darwin 16.7.0 64-bit, Python 3.6.6 (64-bit), Tk8.5.19) using macOS Sierra 10.12.6 on a MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015), 2.9 GHz Intel Core i5, 16 GB 1867 MHz DDR3.

Ways to open files that are noted (as open and/or current) in configuration.ini:
(1) from toolbar File > Open... 

Ways to open files that do *not* get noted (as open and/or current) in configuration.ini:
(1) from Finder (when it is a file opened with Thonny);
(2) from Thonny's Files window (when View > Files is turned on).

The effect of not saving this information in the configuration.ini will be seen the next time Thonny is launched, i.e., the file opened may not be what was expected. For example, if no files were open when Thonny was launched, then some files were opened from Finder and then modified/saved but not closed, then exit Thonny from toolbar File > Exit. Next time Thonny is launched, no files will be opened.

title: Exiting Thonny does not always save an updated configuration.ini
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/479) by Carlos (Bitbucket: [caseminario](https://bitbucket.org/caseminario)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

Hi, I'm running Thonny 2.1.21 (Darwin 16.7.0 64-bit, Python 3.6.6 (64-bit), Tk8.5.19) using macOS Sierra 10.12.6 on a MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015), 2.9 GHz Intel Core i5, 16 GB 1867 MHz DDR3.

Ways to exit Thonny that will save an updated configuration.ini:
(1) from toolbar File > Exit;
(2) clicking x in Thonny window titlebar.

Ways to Exit Thonny that will *not* save an updated configuration.ini:
(1) from toolbar Thonny > Quit;
(2) right-clicking Thonny icon in the Dock and selecting Quit.

The effect of not saving the configuration.ini will be seen the next time Thonny is launched, i.e., the file opened may not be what was expected. For example, if no files were open when Thonny was launched, then some files were opened/modified/saved, then exit Thonny from toolbar Thonny > Quit. Next time Thonny is launched, no files will be opened.

Thanks .. Carlos

title: Morse Code Unsuitable for Install Dialog
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/476) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Installing pre-release 2.2.0b4 yields an install dialog box filled with a rough . (dot) and - (dash) attempt at representing morse code. Even to those extremely familiar with audio morse code this is nearly unreadable. In this particular form, the text is not selectable (which would allow users to use external tools for translation). Further, the spacing makes it extremely difficult to determine where morse characters are supposed to end.

Having a cryptic message, which is unreadable, or readable only with difficulty to most of the population is wholly inappropriate.

Install screens are generally where terms of service or license agreements are presented. Text which is unreadable, or difficult to translate to most users is a, (perhaps) surprisingly, large barrier to use and adoption. Install screens should build user trust and confidence in the program they are installing, not alienate them.

The author of this issue will not be using Thonny as a result, at least for now.

title: Thonny in virtual environment
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/452) by Walt Woods (Bitbucket: [shadowman131](https://bitbucket.org/shadowman131)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

Hi, first off nice work, and thank you for making Thonny public!

I'm having my students install Thonny through a miniconda virtual environment.  At present, running "thonny" from this environment requires an extra step: setting "Tools -> Options -> Interpreter" to be the interpreter corresponding with the virtual environment.

I believe it is a bug that Thonny does not use "sys.executable" as the default interpreter in virtual environments.  Plugins, etc. seem to load correctly from the virtual environment.  This is misleading to beginners who will use e.g. "pip install" from the terminal, and then launch Thonny, only to find that their pip installed package is not accessible (because the interpreter is wrong).  I am aware that Thonny has its own package installer, and if Thonny is being run as its own, self-contained Python installation that's great, but if it's being run from a virtual environment, it's the wrong behavior.

I see that Thonny 2.2.0b4 has an option for "The same interpreter which runs Thonny." 
 Great!  Except it should be the default if Thonny is running in a virtual environment.

Thank you.

title: AttributeError: 'ModuleContext' object has no attribute 'children'
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/450) by Miro Hrončok (Bitbucket: [hroncok](https://bitbucket.org/hroncok)
 GitHub: [hroncok](https://github.com/hroncok)
).**

----------------------------------------

Thonny fails to build in Fedora:

```
_____________________________ test_regular_closed ______________________________
    def test_regular_closed():
    
        expected_local = {('5.4', '5.12'),
                          ('6.10', '6.18'),
                          ('6.21', '6.29'),
                          }
    
        text_widget = tkinter.Text()
        text_widget.insert("end", TEST_STR1)
    
        highlighter = LocalsHighlighter(text_widget)
    
>       actual_local = highlighter.get_positions()
thonny/test/plugins/test_locals_marker.py:29: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
thonny/plugins/locals_marker.py:20: in get_positions
    return self._get_positions_correct_but_using_private_parts()
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
self = <thonny.plugins.locals_marker.LocalsHighlighter object at 0xf61108cc>
    def _get_positions_correct_but_using_private_parts(self):
        from jedi import Script
    
        tree = jedi_utils.import_tree()
    
        locs = []
    
        def process_scope(scope):
            if isinstance(scope, tree.Function):
                # process all children after name node,
                # (otherwise name of global function will be marked as local def)
                local_names = set()
                global_names = set()
                for child in scope.children[2:]:
                    process_node(child, local_names, global_names)
            else:
                for child in scope.subscopes:
                    process_scope(child)
    
        def process_node(node, local_names, global_names):
            if isinstance(node, tree.GlobalStmt):
                global_names.update([n.value for n in node.get_global_names()])
    
            elif isinstance(node, tree.Name):
                if node.value in global_names:
                    return
    
                if node.is_definition(): # local def
                    locs.append(node)
                    local_names.add(node.value)
                elif node.value in local_names: # use of local
                    locs.append(node)
    
            elif isinstance(node, tree.BaseNode):
                # ref: jedi/parser/grammar*.txt
                if node.type == "trailer" and node.children[0].value == ".":
                    # this is attribute
                    return
    
                if isinstance(node, tree.Function):
                    global_names = set() # outer global statement doesn't have effect anymore
    
                for child in node.children:
                    process_node(child, local_names, global_names)
    
        source = self.text.get('1.0', 'end')
        script = Script(source + ")") # https://github.com/davidhalter/jedi/issues/897
        module = jedi_utils.get_module_node(script)
>       for child in module.children:
E       AttributeError: 'ModuleContext' object has no attribute 'children'
thonny/plugins/locals_marker.py:86: AttributeError
===================== 1 failed, 20 passed in 0.47 seconds ======================
```

I believe this is due to jedi 0.12 that got updated in Fedora rawhide.

title: Thonny.exe is not digitally signed
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/431) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

The installer itself from https://bitbucket.org/plas/thonny/downloads/thonny-2.1.17.exe is signed by "University of Tartu Institute of Computer Science". That cert allows per-user installation of Thonny into C:\Users\<username>\AppData\...\Thonny folder. Modern Windows 10+ technology called AppLocker prevents running unsecure code in Windows. The Thonny.exe (inside installation folder C:\Users\<username>\AppData\...\Thonny) itself is not signed what does not allow the EXE to be run under Windows 10 with AppLocker enabled. Please sign Thonny.exe with same certificate ("University of Tartu Institute of Computer Science").

title: Autocomplete error
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/423) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Hello,
thank you for your time creating this simple and easy to use IDE.
I think I've encountered an error, but I am not an experienced programmer so it might be my own doing. In this code I am importing pyo (a module for digital signal processing) and making a server s.

In certain contexts pressing ctrl+space after 's.' works fine (see third image) but other times it generates errors (first and second image).

![Autocomplete error](https://i.imgur.com/QyYrWxq.png)


```
from pyo import *
s = Server(sr=48000, buffersize=512, duplex=0, winhost="mme")

s.boot()              #boot server
print(s.getIsBooted)

s.start()
print(s.getIsStarted)

s. #problem here
```

title: Edit keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V, etc.) should work with any language keyboard layout
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/422) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

If the keyboard language is left to some non-latin (Greek, in my case) then Ctlr+C, Ctrl+A, Ctrl+V, etc. don't work as edit shortcuts. The user has to switch back to English for the shortcuts to work.

This is quite a nuisance in IDLE and I thought it would not exist in Thonny (Windows 7 OS). I type some code and switch to Greek in order to type some string. Then I select some text, press Ctrl+C, followed by Ctrl+V somewhere else, only to find out that nothing was copied to clipboard, because the Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V, with my keyboard in Greek where interpreted as Ctrl+ψ and Ctrl+ω, respectively by Thonny, just like with IDLE.

 In windows applications such Ctrl+[letter] keyboard shortcuts work flawlessly no matter what the keyboard language is set to.

Could there be some config file to add to the Cut, Copy, Paste, Select All, Undo, Redo, Find  Replace operations respective shortcuts, as they now fail with the combinations Ctrl+[non-latin Letter]?

title: Logging with logging.error() etc. not working
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/419) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

A simple test program:

```
import logging
logging.error("test")
```

does not create any output (running under different linux distributionss, e.g. Ubuntu 16.04, opensuse 42.3)

```
import sys
print("test", file=sys.stderr)
```

is working as expected.

A simple testcase ist attached.

```
ACTUAL BEHAVIOR:
>>> %Run thonny-logging.py
  test print to stderr
>>> 

EXPECTED OUTPUT:
>>> %Run thonny-logging.py
  ERROR:root:test logging
  test print to stderr
>>>
```

title: traceback missing in connection with pyqt5
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/414) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

using pyqt5 for the GUI, I get non relevant traceback when an error occurs.

Example:


```
from PyQt5 import QtCore, QtGui, QtWidgets
import sys
from PyQt5.uic import loadUiType
Ui_MainWindow, QMainWindow = loadUiType("test9.ui")

class Main(QMainWindow, Ui_MainWindow):
    """Main window"""
    def __init__(self,parent=None):
        super(Main, self).__init__(parent)
        self.setupUi(self)
        self.pushButton.clicked.connect(self.testfunc)

    def testfunc(self):
        print(9/0)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app = QtWidgets.QApplication(sys.argv)
    main = Main()
    main.show()
    sys.exit(app.exec_())
```


The QT form just contains a default pushButton. division/0 expectedly throws an error, but the traceback received is this (and that does not point to the line causing the error)

title: Internal Error when opening Manage Packages on clean install
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/411) by Dan Schellenberg (Bitbucket: [schellenberg](https://bitbucket.org/schellenberg)
 GitHub: [schellenberg](https://github.com/schellenberg)
).**

----------------------------------------

I have replicated this bug on both Windows and Mac. To replicate the error, delete both the .thonny folder at user root, as well as the application itself. Then install the most recent version of Thonny (2.1.16) from the thonny.org website. On both Mac and Windows, an Internal Error pops up when the user selects Manage Packages. The error message reads:


```
    Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/tkinter/__init__.py", line 1699, in __call__
    return self.func(*args)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/tkinter/__init__.py", line 745, in callit
    func(*args)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/plugins/pip_gui.py", line 266, in poll_completion
    self._update_list(json.loads(raw_data))
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/json/__init__.py", line 354, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 342, in decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Extra data", s, end)
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Extra data: line 2 column 1 (char 83)
```

The reason I found the error is that all 30 of my students encountered the bug when they opened Manage Packages on their various machines today. After attempting to install a package, the students then received an error message similar to the following:


```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/tkinter/__init__.py", line 1699, in __call__
    return self.func(*args)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/tkinter/__init__.py", line 745, in callit
    func(*args)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/plugins/pip_gui.py", line 266, in poll_completion
    self._update_list(json.loads(raw_data))
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/json/__init__.py", line 354, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "/Applications/Thonny.app/Contents/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 342, in decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Extra data", s, end)
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Extra data: line 2 column 1 (char 207)
```

For most students, they were still able to use the package that they attempted to install, though it did not show up on the Manage Packages list.

title: auto-complete
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/406) by Anonymous.**

title: debugger failed for python decorator
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/388) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

User is using Mac. If we run the following code, everything is fine. However if use Debug and try to Step Into (F7) the code, the debugger crash when reading the @my_dec annotation.

```
def my_dec(some_function):
    
    def wrapper():
        print("Before")
        
        some_function()
        
        print("After")
        
    return wrapper


@my_dec
def just_some_function():
    print("Yooo!")
    
just_some_function()
```

title: Error upon having the shell output invalid characters
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/365) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open Thonny
2. Write the following to shell
```
print('\U000105b8')
```

Turns out that tkinter can't handle characters which codepoints exceed 0xFFFF (2^16). Similar issues in StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46173519/tkinter-tclerror-character-u1f449-is-above-the-range-u0000-uffff-allowed-b

On a Raspberry Pi, I wired up a button to GND and GPIO 4 and executed this code in Thonny:
```
from gpiozero import Button
mybutton = Button(4)

title: Linux installer fails if invoked with relative, local user path
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/321) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

./install ../temp/ -> ends up trying to write things to /usr/ because the absolute path is not correctly identified and 'if target_dir.startswith("/home")' evaluates to False:

target_dir: ../temp/thonny

In install.py change
	
```
parent_dir = os.path.expanduser(sys.argv[1].strip().rstrip("/"))
```

to
	
```
parent_dir = os.path.abspath(sys.argv[1])
```

body:

I am not sure if this is Linux only.

```
#!

./install installed
Copying files to installed/thonny .................................... 
[('', '', "[Errno 36] File name too long: ''")]
```

title: Linux install script needs quoting around the path(s)
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/319) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

The install script needs quoting around the "$THIS_DIR" path otherwise it will error on a pwd with spaces in it.

For example change
	python3 $THIS_DIR/install.py "$@"
to
	python3 "$THIS_DIR"/install.py "$@"

title: tkinter *destroy()* function does not work properly on Mac OSX
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/317) by swebzarer (Bitbucket: [swebzarer](https://bitbucket.org/swebzarer)
 ).**

----------------------------------------

Hi,

In version 2.1.11 I've noticed that an application with widget.destroy() function cannot be finished and closed correctly. There is no problem when using Anaconda Python SPYDER ver. 3.2.

How to reproduce: just launch this test code:


```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

import tkinter as tk

def but_ex_1():
    print("Will it be destroyed?")
    root.destroy()
    
root = tk.Tk()
tk.Label(root, text="This is a window.").pack()
tk.Button(root, text="OK, go", command=but_ex_1).pack()
root.mainloop()

print("It did/not???")
```

The OSX 10.11.6 cannot finish this widget and it is hung forever. Again, in Spyder 3.2 such bug is undetectable.

What's happening in Thonny engine?

title: Exceptions thrown when debugging a function call whith parameter naming
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/316) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

Hello,
First thank you for your nice job.
I had a problem with experimenting the debugger with a function called with named parameters on Linux.
I reproduced it  with the folowing program :



```
def fact(n):
    if n == 0:
        return 1
    else:
        return fact(n-1) * n    
print("Its factorial is ", fact(n = 3))

```

It crashes when trying to step into fact after evaluating the parameter.
The messages are :


```
ERROR: Problem when handling 'DebuggerProgress'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/adhome/r/rs/r.schneider/P11/Python/thonny/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/workbench.py", line 773, in event_generate
    handler(event)

    self._main_frame_visualizer.update_this_and_next_frames(msg)
  File "/adhome/r/rs/r.schneider/P11/Python/thonny/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/plugins/debugger.py", line 264, in update_this_and_next_frames
    self._update_this_frame(msg, frame_info)
  File "/adhome/r/rs/r.schneider/P11/Python/thonny/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/plugins/debugger.py", line 299, in _update_this_frame
    self._expression_box.update_expression(msg, frame_info)
  File "/adhome/r/rs/r.schneider/P11/Python/thonny/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thonny/plugins/debugger.py", line 430, in update_expression
    id_str = memory.format_object_id(msg.value["id"])
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable

```

Regards,
Raymond Schneider
University of Strasbourg

title: English grammar problems on Thonny home page
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/294) by Anonymous.**

----------------------------------------

"You can also use separate Python installation": need to add "a" before "separate"

"Initial user interface is stripped from all features": better as "The initial user interface is stripped of all features"

"reminds that same name doesn't always mean same variable" would be better as "reminds you that the same name doesn't always mean the same variable"

"API-s" should be "APIs"

"taken care by Thonny" should be "taken care of by Thonny" (yes I know some learners of English think you can't have "of" and "by" right next to each other, but trust me I'm a native: "taken care of" is treated as a single idiomatic phrase here)

+ I think "so that you need to run only single simple installer" would be clearer as "so just one simple installer is needed"

title: Internal error when saving to a read-only folder/file
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/284) by fizban (Bitbucket: [fizban](https://bitbucket.org/fizban)
 GitHub: [fizban](https://github.com/fizban)
).**

----------------------------------------

When opening a read-only file, modifying it and trying to run it, an internal error message appears indicating a PermissionError exception. 

I often use files in read-only folders to allow students to start a script with some boiler-plate code already in place. When they start modifying it and testing it, this internal error message they get frequently confuses them.

Other applications just display the "save as..." window in this event, which forces the students to save the script in their apropriate personal folder.

title: Wrong Unindentation with SHIFT+TAB when last line does not end with CR
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/281) by fizban (Bitbucket: [fizban](https://bitbucket.org/fizban)
 GitHub: [fizban](https://github.com/fizban)
).**

----------------------------------------

When pressing SHIFT+TAB on an indented text in Windows, the unindentation does not behave properly in the event that the selection includes the last line and the last line does not end with a new line.

Steps to reproduce:

1.- Create a file with:

```
# 1st line
    # 2nd line
```
Note that there is no new line after the second line. 

2.- Place the cursor anywhere within the second line and press SHIFT+TAB to unindent it. 

Result: the second line moves at the end of the first line.

title: Occasional incorrect line numbering
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/266) by fizban (Bitbucket: [fizban](https://bitbucket.org/fizban)
 GitHub: [fizban](https://github.com/fizban)
).**

----------------------------------------

When a python script is longer than the window size  and the last action was below the first visible window there are other instances where the line numbers are incorrectly displayed.

For example, when undoing the last action, the numbering of the side is wrongly displayed. The number 1 is assigned to the first visible line, when in reality the line 1 is above the visible line.


Steps to reproduce:

1.- Open Thonny. Write
```
 # line 1
```
 in the first line

2.- Press ENTER until the first line disappears from the visible area.

3.- Type 

```
# last line
```

The line numbers get recalculated and fhe first visible line gets the 1

4.- Press ENTER. The line numbers are properly displayed.

5.- Undo the last action (the ENTER). The line numbers are still properly displayed

6.- Undo once more the last action and the line numbers are wrong again.

"""

def list_minimum(numbers):

def run_example():

title: Copy-paste doesn't work after a while?
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/247) by me.**

----------------------------------------

https://moodle.ut.ee/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=319310#p854508

*"copy/paste teatud hetkedel peale mõningast pruukimist ei töötanud enam. Tuli teha restart ja siis jälle töötas mõnda aega.. "*

*"Mul on tihti Thonny-s mitu erinevat .py laiendiga faili lahti. Ühega töötan ja teisest kopeerin midagi sellesse, millega töötan.
Ka Thonny 2.1.1 juhtub päris tihti nii, et alguses saan seda operatsioni teha, aga peale mõnigast töötamist enam mitte.
Veateadet ei tule, aga mällu kopeeritud asjad ühest failist ei asetu teise faili.
Näiteks olgu mul lahti kaks faili Test1.py ja Test2.py. Soovin kopeerida Test1. py failist mingi jupi ja asetada selle Test2.py faili.
Kui programmi algul käima panen, siis see õnnestub kenasti, kui peale mõningast tööd enam mitte. Pean tegema Thonnyle restardi ja siis jälle õnnestub mõnda aega."*

title: Set application specific WM_CLASS
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/237) by Gregor S. (Bitbucket: [gsantner](https://bitbucket.org/gsantner)
 GitHub: [gsantner](https://github.com/gsantner)
).**

----------------------------------------

Please set a WM_CLASS specific to this application, so it can be easier distinguished from other running applications and grouped correctly. Thonny may show up as a unknown application in docks as there is no such association, the current WM_CLASS is just the default tk,TK.

![gnome-shell-screenshot-DMDVZY.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/gXnbod/images/2560095970-gnome-shell-screenshot-DMDVZY.png)

This can be modified easily in the __init method for tkinter. See <http://effbot.org/tkinterbook/pythondoc-tkinter-wm.htm> for more details.

If you set e.g. "thonny-ide" this can be added to the *.desktop file to make the association:
`StartupWMClass=thonny-ide`

    print("Pulsisagedus "+ "peaks "+ "olema "+ "vahemikus " + str(N_treening_3min) + " kuni "+ str(N_treening_3max))
```

When implicit concatenation gets replaced with explicit concatenation on line 3, the crash goes away

title: Debugger crashes when encountering a splat (*)
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/151) by Emil Tylén (Bitbucket: [emityl](https://bitbucket.org/emityl)
 GitHub: [emityl](https://github.com/emityl)
).**

----------------------------------------

#### Issue
When stepping through a program, the splat operator (used to separate lists into function arguments) crashes the debugger.

####To reproduce, run the following code:

```
arr = [1,2,3,4,5]

def print_all(a, b, c, d, e):
    print(a, b, c, d ,e)

print_all(*arr)
```

This code runs fine, but debugging it causes an exception.  
If stepping over the call, it throws an `_tkinter.TclError` (attached file stacktrace1.png).

If stepping *into* the call, it instead throws an `AttributeError` (stacktrace2.png)

#####System information
* Thonny 2.0.3
* Windows 10 (64-bit)
* Python 3.5.2 (64-bit)
* Tk 8.6.4

title: AST marker fails (docstring, default values, tuple assignment)
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/149) by me.**

----------------------------------------

code:


```
def pour_problem(X, Y, goal, start=(0,0)):
    """X and Y are the capacity of glassesL (x, y) is curent fill levels
    and represents a stae. The goal is a level that can be in either glass.
    Start at start state and follow successors until we reach the goal.
    Keep trak of frontier and previously explored; fail when no frontier."""
    if goal in start:
        return [start]
    explored = set()
    frontier = [[start]]
    while frontier:
        path = frontier.pop(0)
        (x, y) = path[-1] # Last state in the first path of the frontier
        for (state, action) in successors(x, y, X, Y).items():
            if state not in explored:
                explored.add(state)
                path2 = path + [action, state]
                if goal in state:
                    return path2
                else:
                    frontier.append(path2)
    return Fail

Fail = []

def successors(x, y, X, Y):
    """Return a dict of {state: action} pairs describing what can be reached from
    the (x, y) state and how"""
    assert x<=X and y<=Y
    return {((0, y+x) if y+x<=Y else (x-(Y-y), y+(Y-y))): 'X->Y',
            ((x+y, 0) if x+y<=X else (x+(X-x), y-(X-x))): 'Y->X',
            (X, y): 'fill X', (x, Y): 'fill Y',
            (0, y): 'empty X', (x, 0): 'empty Y'}


print(pour_problem(4, 9, 6))

title: Attribute gets incorrectly marked as local variable
body:
**[Original report](https://bitbucket.org/bitbucket-issue-migration\thonny-issues.zip/issue/112) by me.**

----------------------------------------

In the following .event is highlighted as local:


```
import pygame
from pygame.locals import *

pygame.init()
surface = pygame.display.set_mode((400,300))
pygame.display.set_caption("Gello")

def mainloop():
    while True:
        for event in pygame.event.get():
            if event.type == QUIT:
                pygame.quit()
                return
        pygame.display.update()

mainloop()
```
